header: I am sure you are aware the archive of the Perl Weekly. If not, check out the web site. You'll find it. It is displayed in chronological order, but as some people prefer to have the latest at the top, now you can see it in reverse chronological order, and you can even have a list of all the posts with all the titles. This will make it easier for you to locate a post you saw earlier on the Perl Weekly. What else would you like to see? Is there some other slice of the history of the Perl Weekly posts that you'd like to see? Let me know!

entries.title: Pinto on FLOSS Weekly next Wednesday
entries.text: Jeffrey Ryan Thalhammer, the author of Perl::Critic and Pint is going to be interview on the FLOSS Weekly on March 26 at 8:30 Pacific Time. You can see him live.

entries.title: YAPC::NA Austin â€“ Call for speakers extended to end of March 2013
YAPC::Asia Tokyo 2013 Dates and Location
entries.text: Septempber 19 through 21, 2013 in Keio University Hiyoshi Campus, Tokyo

entries.title: CPAN Testers Summary - March 2013 - Us
entries.text: While testing might not be exciting for many, I think it is one of the awesome areas in Perl. I am really glad Barbie and co. keep working on the CPAN Testers infrastructure and he keeps reporting.

entries.title: No more copy and paste: How to refactor tests with roles
entries.text: Tests are just more code, but when it gets to testing, even the best programmers might revert to the ancient art of copy-paste. But this is David Golden. He did not want to repeate his code so he wrote a module called Test::Roo to make it easy to use roles in testing. (And the comments are also interesting to read.)

entries.title: Reinstating Class::MOP's Commit History in Moose
entries.text: This is actually more bout Git than about Perl, but it can be quite useful for you!

entries.title: Reading from a file in Perl 6
entries.text: One of the basics you need to learn before Perl 6 becomes useful to you.

entries.title: Hashes in Perl
entries.text: Inroducing hashes. Just another part of the Perl Tutorial.

chapters.title: Events
chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
